abstract.p: Tom Welander letter on Michael Benanav's August 8 article on boating on the Yampa River holds National Park Service's permit system is unfair to public; Christopher R Moos, administrative officer of Dinosaur National Monument, responds

block.p: To the Editor: Regarding ''Awe, Fun and Peril on a Wild River,'' (Aug. 8) Michael Benanav's article about the Yampa River, the National Park Service deserves Mr. Benanav's salute for managing the amount of visitor traffic on the Yampa. But I feel that the permit system unfairly allocates this public resource.

To the Editor: Regarding ''Awe, Fun and Peril on a Wild River,'' (Aug. 8) Michael Benanav's article about the Yampa River, the National Park Service deserves Mr. Benanav's salute for managing the amount of visitor traffic on the Yampa. But I feel that the permit system unfairly allocates this public resource.

Unlike the successful Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness permit system, which gives self-guided and commercially guided visitors equal access, the Yampa system provides no-wait access to commercial trips and a lottery for self-guided citizens. The public is cheated because this system gives our outdoors to a company that sells it back to us as a scarce resource, ultimately denying access to those who don't pay.
Christopher R. Moos, administrative officer of the Dinosaur National Monument, responds:

The Dinosaur National Monument River Management Plan states that every year we offer a 50/50 split between commercial and private permits (300 each during high-use season from May 10 to Sept. 9 this year). The public is in no way ''cheated.''
The river plan requires that everyone pays a fee to use the river -- whether commercial or private. It's not the case that individuals or groups go free if they are successful in the lottery.

And the plan does not necessarily provide ''no-wait access'' for commercial trips. Commercial boaters have limits on the number of people they take on any given trip and trips per season. Therefore, the wait depends ultimately on the competition between potential customers for those seats.
